Award.AwardTitle: Local to Global: Using Science Visualizations to Improve Earth System Science Literacy
Award.AbstractNarration: Local to Global (L2G) is a project conducted by the Lawrence Hall of Science (the Hall) and the Berkeley Seismological Laboratory (BSL), both divisions of the University of California, Berkeley. The proof-of-concept project seeks to merge two display systems - the Active Earth Display kiosk from the NSF-sponsored Incorporated Research Institutions for Seismology (IRIS) and the Science On a Sphere (SOS)Â® from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) - to tell compelling local seismic stories in a global context. The project is creating a model for using local seismic events, data, and research to develop public understanding of key geoscience concepts. Seismic activity has a motivating immediacy - people want to know more when something happens (or could happen) that impacts their lives. As a phenomenon the public is already aware of, this is a springboard to learn how local seismic events fit into the global picture of seismology. Science centers like the Hall and research facilities like BSL are both actively sought out by the public and the press when questions arise about seismic events. By linking two real-time data display systems, the public will have a tool to delve into the science behind current seismic events that pique interest and questions. L2G will build on the Hall's earlier work using large-format scientific data visualizations to promote public understanding by encouraging visitors to look for patterns, make predictions, and compare their findings to scientists' findings. This model will be disseminated to existing networks, including over 70 SOS institutions with the infrastructure to support its implementation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Local to Global: Using Science Visualizations to Improve Earth System Science Literacy project was a partnership between the Lawrence Hall of Science and the Berkeley Seismological Laboratory—both at the University of California, Berkeley—funded by the NSF Geoscience Education Program (NSF 10-512). It was a proof-of-concept project designed to create a new, interactive visitor control kiosk for the Science On a Sphere (SOS)—developed and maintained by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)—to tell compelling local seismic narratives in a global context. The SOS is a large-format spherical display system for displaying global data. There are over 100 SOS installations around the world, and over 450 datasets to explore. 

The project created a model for the use of local seismic events, data, and research to develop public understanding of key geoscience concepts. In particular, the model emphasized a collaboration between scientific subject matter experts and museum professionals with the experience to successfully translate the complex science into intuitive language for the general public.

Over the two-year project period, the team created two narratives and developed a brand-new visitor control kiosk from the ground up. Like previous kiosks, this one gives visitors choices on the data to observe and the ability to manipulate the orientation (i.e., the rotation) of the dataset. New, however, was the format of the kiosk with its narrative organization. Instead of offering a selection of individual datasets, this kiosk organized multiple datasets under a unifying narrative. In this way, the kiosk is able to share a story that provides deeper understanding of concepts by making explicit the connection between different seismic visualizations. Since the kiosk is HTML-based, this also makes it easily updateable when new seismic events of note occur.

The first narrative provided background on common disasters that result from earthquakes—tsunamis, building collapse, and liquefaction—using examples of earthquakes from around the world. All these are also concerns locally in the seismically active San Francisco Bay Area. The second narrative explores the concept of seismic waves, and how researchers—including those at the collaborating Berkeley Seismological Laboratory—use seismic waves to explore the interior of our planet. In both narratives, information on the kiosk was complemented by global visualizations on the SOS showing earthquakes around the world over time, models of tsunamis flowing across entire oceans, seismic surfaces waves speeding across the entire globe like ripples in a pond, and more.

As part of the narrative creation, two brand-new datasets were also created and published to the SOS Data Catalog, maintained by NOAA. One shows seismic surface waves propagating across the globe from the 1994 Northridge earthquake, and the other shows a 50-year history of earthquakes and major volcanic eruptions. Both are accessible by any SOS installed around the world, and can be previewed by anyone online at the Data Catalog website.

The SOS is still a relatvely new platform, but holds enormous potential for education and public outreach in Earth sciences. Its intuitive global display coupled with the power to explore change over time makes it a powerful tool to help the public understand complex global phenomena. The Local to Global kiosk provides a means to develop and share real scientific narratives with the public and deepen their knowledge of the world.
